data.title: This Week in History: 1971 PM Pierre Trudeau marries Margaret Sinclair
data.meta_description: On March 4, 1971, Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau flew to Vancouver for what was described as a ski trip.
data.text:
Article content

On March 4, 1971, Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau flew to Vancouver for what was described as a ski trip.

He did go skiing. But not alone.

Trudeau flew into Vancouver at 6:30 p.m., hopped in a car and drove to St. Stephen’s Roman Catholic Church in North Vancouver, where “the most eligible bachelor of international politics” married Margaret Sinclair of West Van.

Only a dozen family members were at the ceremony — and no members of the press. Even his cabinet ministers were kept in the dark.

“The (marriage) was kept so secret that only one of the bride’s four sisters, the bridesmaid, knew of the wedding until the last minute — the others thought they were dressing up for a ‘family portrait’,” reported The Province.

“Rev. John Swinkels, the Roman Catholic priest who performed the ceremony and the wedding photographer had been told that Margaret Sinclair was marrying a ‘Pierre Mercier’.”

Province photographer Bill Cunningham lived near the Sinclair home in the British Properties. He got a tip something was up, and arrived to find Pierre and Margaret leaving the Sinclair house.

Cunningham’s memorable photo of the beaming couple being showered in rice took up most of the front page of the March 5 paper, under the giant headline “PM SECRETLY WEDS W. VAN. GIRL HERE.”

The Sun’s headline was “After Secret Wedding Here, PM Honeymoons at Whistler”. It ran several pages of photos, some by wedding photographer Fred Schiffer, others by The Sun’s Ken Oakes from the reception at the Capilano Golf and Country Club.

Both papers played up Margaret’s age, 22. That was 29 years younger than Pierre.

“He may be old but he’s a young man at heart,” said Margaret’s mother Kathleen, who was two years younger than her new son-in-law. “They are very well suited to each other and it has been a happy courtship.”

B.C. newspaper legend Ma Murray predicted marriage would make Trudeau “a hell of a lot smarter”.

“God, he should have done it 30 years ago,” said the 83-year-old Murray. “He’s going to have a hard time living up to the requirements of a 22-year-old bride, but I wish him lots of luck.”

According to the papers, the couple met in Tahiti in 1967, where the Sinclair family was on vacation. Pierre knew Margaret’s dad James, who was a prominent west coast Liberal.

Margaret worked in Ottawa in 1969, and that August Sun photographer Dan Scott took a photo of Trudeau and Margaret having an “intimate dinner” at a restaurant atop Grouse Mountain.

But the PM’s name continued to be linked with many women, including singer Barbra Streisand, until his surprise wedding.

Sun columnist Allan Fotheringham recalled his first encounter with Margaret in March 1968, when he noticed a “charming little smasher bouncing up and down with excitement” at the prospect of seeing Trudeau.

“Her eyes sparkled and she kept asking her girlfriend ‘Do you think he’ll remember me?’” Fotheringham wrote.

“When Trudeau appeared she jumped in front of him, kissed him on both cheeks and asked, in shy wonderment, her face turned up to his, if he remembered. He did indeed.”

The papers reported that Margaret had made their three-tiered wedding cake herself. They noted that the wedding party went through six bottles of champagne at the reception. And they wrote the couple sped off in an RCMP cruiser.

The couple honeymooned at Whistler, where the Sinclair family had a cabin. Trudeau joked to the hordes of reporters that met him on the slopes that marrying Margaret was his “first centennial project” for B.C., which had entered Confederation in 1871.

The Sun asked Montreal astrologer John Manolesco to make some predictions about the marriage.

“Rummaging through his charts and astrology books, Mandolesco forecast there will be two children in the marriage — and all the signs point towards girls,” said The Sun story.

“In short, he said, the marriage between Trudeau the Libra and Margaret the Virgo will be successful.”

Just over nine months after the marriage, Margaret gave birth to a son, Justin, on Christmas Day, 1971. The couple would have two more sons, and separated in 1977.
